questions.question: Jury duty pay that an employee turns over to their employer is:

options.B: Reported as income and deductible as an above-the-line adjustment
options.C: Reported as income with no deduction available

questions.explanation: Jury duty pay is taxable income. When an employee is required to remit the pay to their employer (who continues paying wages during service), the employee reports the income and claims an above-the-line deduction for the amount remitted to the employer.
questions.tip: Jury pay remitted to employer: report income, deduct as adjustment. No double-counting with wages.

questions.question: Under the mailbox rule, an acceptance is effective when:

options.B: Properly dispatched (mailed)

questions.explanation: The mailbox rule provides that an acceptance is effective upon proper dispatch (placing in the mail with proper postage), not upon receipt. This creates the contract and cuts off the offeror's power to revoke. Rejections and revocations are effective upon receipt.
questions.tip: Acceptance: effective on dispatch. Rejection/revocation: effective on receipt. Creates certainty for offeree.

questions.question: When property is received as a gift and the donor's basis is used, the donee's holding period:

options.A: Starts on the date of the gift
options.B: Includes the donor's holding period (tacking)
options.D: Starts when the donee sells the property

questions.explanation: When the donee uses carryover basis (donor's basis), the holding period 'tacks'—the donee includes the donor's holding period. If FMV at gift is less than basis and FMV is used for loss, the holding period starts on the gift date.
questions.tip: Carryover basis = tacking allowed. FMV basis (for loss) = holding period starts at gift date.

questions.question: When property is contributed to a partnership in exchange for a partnership interest, the transaction is generally:

options.A: Fully taxable to the contributing partner
options.B: Tax-free to the partner and partnership
options.C: Taxable only if gain is realized

questions.explanation: Under Section 721, contributions of property to a partnership in exchange for a partnership interest are tax-free to both the partner and partnership. The partner takes a substituted basis in their partnership interest equal to the property's basis.
questions.tip: Section 721: tax-free formation. Basis carries over. Compare to Section 351 for corporations.

questions.question: Written tax advice covered by Circular 230 must:

options.B: Not be based on unreasonable assumptions and must consider all relevant facts

questions.explanation: Written tax advice must not be based on unreasonable factual or legal assumptions, must consider all relevant facts the practitioner knows or should know, and must not unreasonably rely on statements of the taxpayer. Practitioners must use reasonable efforts to identify relevant facts.
questions.tip: Circular 230 written advice: reasonable assumptions, consider all facts, identify limitations.

questions.question: For a taxpayer with prior year AGI of $180,000, the safe harbor for estimated taxes requires payment of at least:

options.B: 100% of prior year tax
options.C: 110% of prior year tax or 90% of current year tax

questions.explanation: For taxpayers with prior year AGI over $150,000 ($75,000 MFS), the safe harbor requires 110% of prior year tax. The alternative is 90% of current year tax. Meeting either test avoids the underpayment penalty.
questions.tip: AGI > $150K: 110% prior year OR 90% current year. Under $150K: 100% prior year OR 90% current year.

questions.question: Under current law, moving expenses are deductible for:

options.A: Any taxpayer who moves for employment
options.B: Only members of the Armed Forces on active duty moving pursuant to military orders
options.D: No one—moving expenses are no longer deductible

questions.explanation: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act suspended the moving expense deduction for all taxpayers except active duty members of the Armed Forces moving due to a military order. For military members, expenses remain deductible above-the-line and employer reimbursements are excludable.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: moving expenses only for active duty military. Suspended for all others through 2025.

questions.question: Under the common law Statute of Frauds, which contract must be in writing?

options.A: A contract for the sale of a car for $400
options.B: A one-year employment contract starting tomorrow
options.C: A two-year lease of an apartment

questions.explanation: Common law Statute of Frauds requires writing for: contracts that cannot be performed within one year, promises to pay another's debt, contracts for sale of land, marriage-related promises, and executor promises. A 2-year lease qualifies; a 1-year contract starting tomorrow can be performed within a year.
questions.tip: MY LEGS: Marriage, Year (can't complete in 1 year), Land, Executor, Goods ($500+), Surety.

questions.question: When a C corporation distributes appreciated property to a shareholder, the corporation:

options.B: Recognizes gain as if the property were sold at fair market value
options.D: Defers gain until the shareholder sells

questions.explanation: When a corporation distributes appreciated property, it recognizes gain as if it sold the property for FMV. The shareholder receives a FMV basis. For depreciated property, loss is not recognized unless it's a complete liquidation. This prevents corporations from distributing appreciation tax-free.
questions.tip: Appreciated property distribution: corp recognizes gain. Loss not recognized on non-liquidating distributions.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, realized gain is calculated as:

options.A: FMV of property received minus FMV of property given
options.B: FMV of property received plus boot received minus adjusted basis of property given
options.D: FMV of boot received minus basis of boot given

questions.explanation: Realized gain = Amount realized (FMV of property received + boot received + liabilities relieved) minus Adjusted basis of property given. Recognized gain is the lesser of realized gain or boot received.
questions.tip: Realized = Amount received - Adjusted basis given. Recognized = lesser of realized or boot.

questions.question: Apparent authority arises when:

options.A: The principal expressly grants authority to the agent
options.B: The principal's conduct causes a third party to reasonably believe the agent is authorized
options.C: The agent believes they have authority
options.D: The authority is implied from the agent's position

questions.explanation: Apparent authority is created by the principal's manifestations to third parties that lead them to reasonably believe the agent has authority. Even if actual authority doesn't exist, the principal is bound if they created the appearance of authority.
questions.tip: Apparent authority: principal's conduct → third party's reasonable belief. Principal estopped from denying.

questions.question: Distributions from an S corporation with no accumulated E&P are treated as:

options.A: Dividends to the extent of earnings
options.B: Tax-free return of basis, then capital gain

questions.explanation: For S corporations without C corporation E&P, distributions are first a tax-free return of stock basis, then capital gain when basis is exhausted. If the S corp has accumulated E&P from C corp years, distributions come from AAA first (tax-free), then E&P (dividend), then basis.
questions.tip: No E&P: basis reduction → capital gain. With E&P: AAA → E&P → basis → capital gain.

questions.question: The adoption credit is:

options.B: Nonrefundable, with unused credit carried forward up to 5 years

questions.explanation: The adoption credit is nonrefundable and covers qualified adoption expenses up to a maximum per child (~$16,810 for 2024). Unused credit carries forward for 5 years. Higher amounts may apply for special needs adoptions. Income phaseouts apply.
questions.tip: Adoption credit: nonrefundable, 5-year carryforward. Special needs = full credit even without expenses.

questions.question: Enrolled agents are authorized to:

options.B: Represent taxpayers before all administrative levels of the IRS
options.C: Only prepare returns, not represent clients
options.D: Represent clients only in Tax Court

questions.explanation: Enrolled agents are federally authorized tax practitioners who can represent taxpayers before all administrative levels of the IRS (examinations, appeals, collections). They cannot represent clients in court. EAs are licensed by passing a comprehensive exam or through IRS experience.
questions.tip: EAs: full IRS representation (not courts). Licensed by exam or IRS experience. Regulated by Circular 230.

questions.question: A PMSI in equipment has priority over a prior perfected security interest if:

options.A: Notice is given to prior creditors
options.B: It is perfected within 20 days after the debtor receives possession
options.C: It is perfected before the debtor receives possession
options.D: A financing statement is filed within 30 days

questions.explanation: A PMSI in equipment (non-inventory) has superpriority over prior perfected interests if perfected within 20 days after the debtor receives possession. No notice to prior creditors is required for equipment (unlike inventory). This 20-day grace period makes equipment financing practical.
questions.tip: PMSI equipment: 20-day grace period, no notice. PMSI inventory: before possession + notice to prior creditors.

questions.question: A partner guaranteed a minimum of $50,000 from the partnership. The partner's distributive share is $35,000. The guaranteed payment is:
questions.explanation: A guaranteed minimum ensures the partner receives at least the stated amount. If the distributive share is less, the difference is a guaranteed payment. Here, the partner receives $35,000 distributive share plus $15,000 guaranteed payment to reach the $50,000 minimum.
questions.tip: Guaranteed minimum: payment = minimum - distributive share (if positive). Total = distributive share + guaranteed payment.

questions.question: A qualified distribution from a Roth IRA is:

options.B: Tax-free if the account is 5+ years old and the owner is 59½+ or meets other requirements
options.C: Subject to 10% penalty regardless of age
options.D: Taxable only on the earnings portion

questions.explanation: Qualified Roth IRA distributions (5-year rule + age 59½, death, disability, or first home purchase) are completely tax-free. Nonqualified distributions: contributions come out first (tax-free), then earnings (taxable + possibly 10% penalty).
questions.tip: Qualified Roth: 5-year rule + trigger. Nonqualified: contributions first (tax-free), then taxable earnings.

questions.question: Under Circular 230, a practitioner exercising due diligence:

options.A: May rely on client information without verification in all cases
options.B: Must make reasonable inquiries if information appears incorrect, incomplete, or inconsistent
options.C: Must independently verify all client information
options.D: Has no obligation to question client information

questions.explanation: Due diligence requires practitioners to make reasonable inquiries if furnished information appears incorrect, incomplete, or inconsistent. They may generally rely on client information without verification unless it appears problematic. Common sense investigation of questionable items is required.
questions.tip: Due diligence: can rely on info unless red flags. Must inquire if something seems wrong.

questions.question: Members of a properly maintained LLC are generally:

options.A: Personally liable for all LLC debts
options.B: Protected from personal liability for LLC obligations
options.D: Personally liable if they participate in management

questions.explanation: LLC members enjoy limited liability similar to corporate shareholders—they are not personally liable for LLC debts and obligations beyond their investment. Unlike limited partners, LLC members can participate in management without losing liability protection.
questions.tip: LLC: limited liability + management participation. Unlike LP where active participation = personal liability.

questions.question: Which of the following is an adjustment that increases alternative minimum taxable income (AMTI)?

options.B: State and local tax deduction
options.D: Home mortgage interest on acquisition debt

questions.explanation: State and local taxes (including income and property taxes) are deductible for regular tax but not for AMT, requiring an add-back. Standard deduction, personal exemptions (when applicable), and certain depreciation differences are also AMT adjustments.
questions.tip: AMT add-backs: SALT, personal exemptions, standard deduction, certain depreciation. Not add-back: mortgage interest on acquisition debt.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a capital asset?

options.B: Stock held for investment

questions.explanation: Capital assets include investment property, personal-use property, and collectibles. Exceptions (NOT capital assets) include: inventory, accounts receivable from business, depreciable/real business property (Section 1231), supplies, and certain government publications.
questions.tip: Capital assets: everything EXCEPT inventory, receivables, business property, supplies, some copyrights.

questions.question: The control requirement for a tax-free Section 351 exchange is:

options.B: At least 80% of voting power and 80% of each class of nonvoting stock

questions.explanation: Section 351 requires that transferors, in the aggregate, control the corporation immediately after the exchange. Control means owning at least 80% of total combined voting power AND at least 80% of each class of nonvoting stock. A single transferor or group must meet this test.
questions.tip: Section 351 control: 80% vote + 80% each nonvoting class. Measured immediately after transfer.

questions.question: A trustee in bankruptcy can avoid as a preference a payment made:

options.A: To any creditor within 2 years before filing
options.B: To a creditor for an antecedent debt within 90 days (1 year for insiders) that improved their position

questions.explanation: Preferences are payments made within 90 days (1 year for insiders) for antecedent debts that allow a creditor to receive more than they would in a Chapter 7 liquidation. The trustee can avoid these payments to redistribute them equitably. Exceptions apply for ordinary course payments.
questions.tip: Preference: 90 days (1 year insider), antecedent debt, creditor improved position. Ordinary course = exception.

questions.question: Section 751(b) applies to a distribution that:

options.B: Changes the distributee partner's share of unrealized receivables or substantially appreciated inventory
options.D: Is made to all partners equally

questions.explanation: Section 751(b) recharacterizes disproportionate distributions—those that change a partner's share of 'hot assets' (unrealized receivables and substantially appreciated inventory). The partner is treated as exchanging their share of hot assets for other property, recognizing ordinary income on the exchange.
questions.tip: Section 751(b): disproportionate distribution of hot assets = deemed exchange, ordinary income recognized.

questions.question: A taxpayer may group activities for passive loss purposes if:

options.B: The activities form an appropriate economic unit based on factors like common control, location, and interdependence
options.C: The taxpayer simply wants to maximize losses

questions.explanation: Activities can be grouped if they constitute an appropriate economic unit, considering factors such as: common control, common ownership, geographic location, business interdependence, and similar types of business. Once grouped, the activities are treated as one for passive activity purposes.
questions.tip: Grouping: appropriate economic unit. Factors: control, ownership, location, interdependence, similarity. Consistent treatment required.

questions.question: A penalty for an erroneous claim for refund or credit may be imposed equal to:

options.B: 20% of the excessive amount if due to reckless or intentional disregard

questions.explanation: The erroneous refund penalty is 20% of the excessive amount claimed if due to reckless or intentional disregard of rules or regulations. This applies to claims for refund or credit that have no reasonable basis. The 75% fraud penalty may apply if fraud is involved.
questions.tip: Erroneous refund: 20% for reckless/intentional disregard. Separate from accuracy-related and fraud penalties.

questions.question: To establish a private action under Rule 10b-5, a plaintiff must prove:

options.A: Only that the defendant made a misstatement
options.B: Scienter (intent to deceive), materiality, reliance, and damages
options.D: That the defendant is a securities professional

questions.explanation: Private Rule 10b-5 claims require: (1) misstatement or omission, (2) of material fact, (3) made with scienter (intentional or reckless), (4) in connection with purchase or sale of securities, (5) reliance, and (6) economic loss. Negligence is insufficient—scienter is required.
questions.tip: 10b-5 private action: scienter required (not just negligence). SEC enforcement has lower standard.

questions.question: Distributable Net Income (DNI) serves to:

options.A: Determine the maximum trust tax rate
options.B: Limit the distribution deduction and characterize income to beneficiaries

questions.explanation: DNI limits the distribution deduction the trust can claim and determines the amount and character of income passed through to beneficiaries. It prevents the trust from deducting more than its taxable income and ensures income retains its character (ordinary, capital, etc.) when distributed.
questions.tip: DNI: limits deduction + characterizes income to beneficiaries. Trust/estate splits income with beneficiaries.

questions.question: Sanctions for violations of Circular 230 may include:

options.B: Censure, suspension, or disbarment from practice before the IRS, plus monetary penalties

questions.explanation: Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) sanctions include: censure (public reprimand), suspension from practice, disbarment, and monetary penalties up to gross income from the engagement. These are administrative sanctions; criminal violations are separate matters.
questions.tip: Circular 230 sanctions: censure, suspension, disbarment, monetary penalty. Administrative, not criminal (though can have both).

questions.question: Which of the following may NOT be a shareholder of an S corporation?

options.B: A grantor trust

questions.explanation: S corporation shareholders must be individuals, certain trusts (grantor, voting, testamentary, QSST, ESBT), or estates. Partnerships, corporations, and nonresident aliens are ineligible. If an ineligible shareholder obtains stock, the S election terminates.
questions.tip: Ineligible S shareholders: partnerships, corporations, NRAs. ESBTs and QSSTs specifically allowed.

questions.question: If an installment sale is made to a related party who sells within 2 years, the original seller must:

options.A: Continue deferring gain on the installment method
options.B: Recognize gain accelerated to the extent of the related party's proceeds
options.C: Report all gain as ordinary income
options.D: File an amended return for all prior years

questions.explanation: When a related party resells installment sale property within 2 years, the original seller must recognize gain to the extent of the resale proceeds (up to remaining deferred gain). This prevents using related parties to convert installment sales to cash while deferring gain.
questions.tip: Related party resale < 2 years: original seller accelerates gain. Prevents installment sale abuse.

questions.question: Impracticability differs from impossibility in that impracticability:

options.B: Allows discharge when performance is unreasonably difficult even if not literally impossible
options.C: Only applies to personal service contracts

questions.explanation: Impossibility requires that performance is objectively impossible (death of unique party, destruction of specific goods, illegality). Impracticability allows discharge when an unforeseen event makes performance unreasonably difficult or expensive, even though technically possible.
questions.tip: Impossibility: can't be done at all. Impracticability: unreasonably difficult/expensive. Both require unforeseen events.

questions.question: An activity presumed to be for profit if it shows a profit in:

options.B: 3 of the last 5 years (2 of 7 for horse breeding)

questions.explanation: An activity is presumed to be a for-profit activity (not a hobby) if it produces a profit in 3 of the last 5 years (2 of 7 years for horse activities). The presumption can be rebutted by the IRS. Hobbies cannot generate deductible losses beyond income from the hobby.
questions.tip: Profit presumption: 3 of 5 years (2 of 7 for horses). Hobby = no loss deduction under current law.

questions.question: Property transferred to a revocable trust during life is:

options.B: Included in the grantor's gross estate at death
options.C: Subject to gift tax at transfer
options.D: Taxed only to the trust beneficiaries

questions.explanation: Property in a revocable trust is included in the grantor's gross estate under Section 2038 because the grantor retained the power to alter, amend, revoke, or terminate. This power 'strings' the property back into the estate despite the earlier transfer.
questions.tip: Revocable trust: included in estate (Section 2038). No completed gift during life. Basis stepped up at death.

questions.question: The trust fund recovery penalty may be imposed on:

options.B: Responsible persons who willfully fail to collect, account for, or pay over employment taxes

questions.explanation: The trust fund recovery penalty (100% penalty) applies to 'responsible persons' who willfully fail to collect, account for, or pay over employment taxes withheld from employees. Responsible persons include officers, directors, employees with authority over finances, and even some outside parties.
questions.tip: Trust fund penalty: 100% of tax. Responsible + willful. Can apply to multiple persons. Personal liability.
